The History of Chinese Immigrants in the United States

Creator: Hart, Alfred A

Title: Laborers and rocks, near opening of Summit Tunnel

Date: Between 1865 and 1869

Format: Photograph

Institution: Golden State Photographic Gallery

Link: https://www.loc.gov/item/2005682913/

The history of Chinese immigrants in the United States can be traced back as early as the “Gold Rush” of 1848 - 1855. Chinese immigrants played a significant role in the development and expansion of the transcontinental railroads built in the United States. These Chinese immigrant laborers faced many brutal challenges while working under extreme weather conditions. And despite being paid at a low wage, these Chinese immigrant laborers managed to toe the line. Many of the jobs that these laborers were appointed to do, were viewed to be extremely hazardous. The most dangerous job to be taken was by the “brakemen”. Brakemen would have to traverse over the top of train while running from car to car, to manually hit the brakes. Regardless of rain, snow, or shine. The job of the brakemen was to couple the cars and attach them with a large kingpin. This placed the worker in a very vulnerable position to lose their finger. The photo above was taken by the Central Pacific Railroad, it depicts Chinese laborer’s working under harsh and dangerous conditions. Many of the Chinese immigrant laborers died from landslides. The photo clearly shows the viewer the danger of a lanslide to occur.
